Questions.Question: The human heart is divided into sections called chambers. How many chambers does a human heart have?
Questions.Explanation: The heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. The right atrium receives oxygen-poor blood from the body and pumps it to the right ventricle. The left atrium receives oxygen-rich blood from the lungs and pumps it to the left ventricle. The left ventricle pumps the oxygen-rich blood to the body.

Questions.Question: Some of the heart's chambers are located at the top and some at the bottom. What is the name for the top chambers of the heart?
Questions.Explanation: The two chambers on top are called the atria . If you're talking only about one, call it an atrium. The atria are the chambers that fill with the blood returning to the heart from the body and lungs. The heart has a left atrium and a right atrium.

Questions.Question: What's the name for the bottom chambers of the heart?
Questions.Explanation: The heart has four chambers — two on top and two on bottom: The two bottom chambers are the right ventricle and the left ventricle. These pump blood out of the heart.

Questions.Question: Which blood vessels return blood to the heart?
Questions.Explanation: Blood moves through many tubes called arteries and veins, which together are called blood vessels. The blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart are called arteries. The ones that carry blood back to the heart are called veins.

Questions.Question: The right side of the heart pumps blood to the lungs. What happens in the lungs?
Questions.Explanation: The right side of your heart receives oxygen-poor blood from your veins and pumps it to your lungs, where it picks up oxygen and gets rid of carbon dioxide. The left side of your heart receives oxygen-rich blood from your lungs and pumps it through your arteries to the rest of your body.

Answers.Text: The blood loses carbon dioxide and picks up oxygen.
The blood turns from red to green.

Questions.Question: Most of the blood vessels that carry oxygen-rich blood around the body are called arteries. The largest artery in the body is the aorta.
Between the upper and lower chambers of the heart are some leaf-like structures which help blood to flow in one direction. These structures are called valves.
What is the average size of your heart?
Questions.Explanation: An adult heart has a mass of 250–350 grams (9–12 oz). The heart is often described as the size of a fist: 12 cm (5 in) in length, 8 cm (3.5 in) wide, and 6 cm (2.5 in) in thickness, although this description is disputed, as the heart is likely to be slightly larger.

Answers.Text: The size of a beach ball.
The size of your clenched fist.

Questions.Question: The number of times the heart beats per minute is called the heart rate. All of the following activities would be likely to increase the heart rate except one. Which one?
Questions.Explanation: At rest, the SA node causes your heart to beat about 50 to 100 times each minute. During activity or excitement, your body needs more oxygen-rich blood; the heart rate rises to well over 100 beats per minute. Medications and some medical conditions may affect how fast your heart-rate is at rest and with exercise.

Questions.Question: Which of the following has the thickest wall?
Questions.Explanation: The myocardium is thickest in the left ventricle, as the left ventricle must create a lot of pressure to pump blood into the aorta and throughout systemic circulation.

Questions.Question: Blood enters into the heart because of muscles of
Questions.Explanation: Blood enters the heart through large veins called as vena cava. Blood enters the heart when the muscles of atria relax and it is pumped out when it is contracted.

Questions.Question: Human heart is made up of five compartments.
Questions.Explanation: The answer is false. The human heart is made up of four compartments. There are two auricles which are also called as atrium. The atrium receives the deoxygenated blood. There are two ventricles. This deoxygenated blood enters the left atrium and then the ventricles. From the ventricles, the blood moves to lungs for purification and then is supplied to the body.
